1103426791119568898.text: A lot of tech that is used at a mass scale was initially developed as a solution for those with disabilities. Think voice to text, autocorrect, predictive text. 1103446139628531712.text: “Don’t design to control. Design to GIVE control.” @gerrymcgovern #ux #AEASEA

1103378552538390528.text: The web has become so much a part of everyone’s life that, if there ever was an “average” user, there certainly isn’t an average user now. @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeasea #animation

1103449686038372352.text:
“Stop measuring what you produce. Measure what the customer uses. And then evolve based on that use.”

@GerryMcGovern #aeasea #ux

1103449259985166336.text:
“Digitizing print is not a digital strategy.”

We needed 50 pages in print? Do we still need them here? How can we simplify? @gerrymcgovern #ux #aeasea

1103449015646007296.text: “If most web content writers were in Irish pubs, nobody would sit and drink with them.” @gerrymcgovern #aeasea

1103448722229231616.text: “Simplicity drives value. But we must measure value. If we don’t measure, it’s the tree falling in the forest. Nobody in the organization realizes the value of our work.” @gerrymcgovern #AEASEA #ux

1103448448760610816.text: “Simplicity is a journey, not an event. It’s a constant process.” @gerrymcgovern #aeasea

1103447143094730752.text: Go into the environment, humbly. Learn from use—learn from what your customers are actually doing. Innovate based on that use. @gerrymcgovern #aeasea #ux

1103446859152945152.text: Pinterest arose from an unrelated product. The makers noticed how customers were using an aspect of their product and turned it into Pinterest. That’s agility. @gerrymcgovern #aeasea #ux

1103446679846412288.text: “Agility is the ability to change based on USE.” @gerrymcgovern #aeasea #ux

1103446424199389184.text: “The agile organization isn’t one that has the ability to make CRAP faster. Agile is the measure of your ability to respond to your customers, and the speed with which you can respond to your customers.” @gerrymcgovern #ux #aeasea

1103440185621004288.text: In the old model, the authority figure was at the center of things. Today, the customer is at the center. The metric today is USE, rather than trust—because we use Google + FB (but don’t trust them). @gerrymcgovern #aeasea

1103439260370124800.text: Trust has shifted away from government, corporations, religious leaders, and politicians, and toward our peers. We trust “people like us.” @gerrymcgovern #aeasea

1103425337566752768.text: Solve a very specific problem for one person, and it will help you create better solutions for everyone. @feather #InclusiveDesign #aeasea

1103389505468260352.text: Alternately, you can use a transition animation effect for users who chose prefers-reduced-motion: reduce (and keep the motion effect for other users). @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeasea

1103389200009719809.text: Replacing movement with opacity transformations is a good way to reduce motion while preserving the cognitive (and pleasurable) values animation adds to your site or product. @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeasea

1103387642589196289.text: Reduce != remove.  Folks who want reduced motion aren’t asking for *no* animation, they’re just asking for UX to not make them sick. @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeasea

1103385916523966464.text: The prefers-reduced-motion CSS media feature puts user in control of how much movement and animation our site uses. @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeaseahttps://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media/prefers-reduced-motion …

1103385328545480709.text:
☞   Designing Safer Web Animation For Motion Sensitivity @vlh
#OldGold #InclusiveDesign #aeaseahttps://alistapart.com/article/designing-safer-web-animation-for-motion-sensitivity …

1103384342154240001.text: Constant animation near text is distracting for many users (and can also trigger vestibular disorders). @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeasea

1103383137378160641.text: Trying to read a thing that’s not moving while another element *is* moving can be extremely triggering for some users. Avoid. @vlh #aeasea #InclusiveDesign

1103381734991654912.text: I just learned my nausea if I try to read while riding in a car is a common form of vestibular disorder. @vlh #AEASEA

1103380825767206912.text: Motion animation triggered by interaction should be able to be disabled by the user unless the animation is essential for functionality. @vlh #InclusiveDesign #animation #a11y #AEASEA

1103379988718411776.text: Don’t flash the screen more than 3X in any one second. @vlh #Epilepsy #aeasea #InclusiveDesign #a11y

1103379648912666624.text: Provide a way to pause, stop, or hide any moving, blinking, or scrolling content that lasts more than 5 seconds. Auto-advancing carousels, animated background videos & animations, and autoplaying videos, I’m looking at you. @vlh #InclusiveDesign #aeasea

1103378807963041792.text: #Animation can help with reducing cognitive load, guiding tasks, connecting across contexts, and more. @vlh #aeasea

1103372769440329729.text: Next: @vlh on the marriage of #a11y and animation: “Making Motion Inclusive” at #AEASEA

1103019658930642944.text: link rel=“stylesheet” and script src=“site.js” are render blockers. (HTML won’t render until scripts and styles load.) To work around this, load necessary assets first via server push (in HTTP2). Load the rest asynchronously when possible. @scottjehl #aeasea

1103019034797268992.text: Progressive enhancement is great for hitting your desired performance goal of first meaningful content (AKA first meaningful paint—the number of seconds from time navigation started til the page’s primary content appears on the screen). @scottjehl #aeasea

1103017438382354434.text: Progressive enhancement predated our multi-device world by a decade, yet PE continues to work as a best practice in terms of performance, portability, a11y, SEO, & more. @scottjehl #aeasea

1103007573790212096.text: “Who is testing the A/B test?” Is the script you use to do A/B testing slowing down your site and creating a worse UX? @una #aeasea
